case_vignette: A 1-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of fever and crying while passing urine for 2 days. She was born at term and has been healthy since. Three months ago, she was treated for a urinary tract infection with oral cefixime. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 144/min, and blood pressure is 85/40 mm Hg. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Her leukocyte count is 14,000/mm3. Urine dipstick shows leukocyte esterase and nitrites; urinalysis shows WBCs and gram-negative rods. Urine culture results are pending. Renal ultrasonography shows hydronephrosis of the left kidney. Empirical antimicrobial therapy is initiated, following which the patient's symptoms improve.
question: Which  is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Renal and Genitourinary System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having a fever and crying when I pee for the past two days.
How old are you?
I'm one year old.
Are you experiencing any abdominal or back pain?
No, I'm not feeling any pain in my stomach or back.
Do you have a history of previous urinary tract infections or kidney issues?
Yes, I was treated for a urinary tract infection three months ago.
Have you had any changes in the color or smell of your urine?
I haven't mentioned anything about changes in the color or smell of my urine.
As you're an infant, this information would be directed to your caregiver. Has your caregiver noticed any changes in the color or smell of your urine?
The caregiver hasn't mentioned any changes in the color or smell of my urine.
Is there a history of urinary tract anomalies or kidney diseases in your family?
I haven't mentioned any family history of urinary tract anomalies or kidney diseases.
Final Diagnosis: Urinary Tract Infection (UTI)

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A one-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a fever and crying during urination over the past two days. There is no mention of any pain in the stomach or back. The child was treated for a urinary tract infection three months ago. There is no mention of any changes in the color or smell of the urine and no family history of urinary tract anomalies or kidney diseases. The caregiver has not mentioned any changes in the color or smell of the urine either.
trial_0.multiturn_mcq: Final Diagnosis: A repeat urinary tract infection is suspected given the history and symptoms. The most appropriate next step in the diagnosis would be voiding cystourethrography, especially to evaluate for vesicoureteral reflux given the recurrence of infection in a one-year-old.
